title: Open Science for Music Research
text:
1 Open Science for Music Research
This repository offers a guide to Open Science practices for music research, particularly aimed for music psychology and computational musicology, but also relevant for music information retrieval, music education, music technology, and musicology.
crumbs: 1  Open Science for Music Research

title: Open Science for Music Research
text:
1.1 Reasons for creating this resource
In music research, there is room for improvement in transparency and reproducibility, to widen the accessibility and equity with Open access to publications and data ensures that researchers, practitioners, and the public can benefit from scientific knowledge. Also, innovation and collaboration benefits from Open Science.
crumbs: 1  Open Science for Music Research

title: Open Science for Music Research
section: 1.2 The way this repository has been coordinated
text:
1.2 The way this repository has been coordinated
Collaborative work, online GitHub repository, multiple authors responsible for specific sections, see also Chapter 2.
crumbs: 1  Open Science for Music Research

title: Open Science for Music Research
text:
1.3 Organisation of the repository

Chapter 3 explains the rationale and the broader picture
Chapter 4 covers the availability of research output and publications
Chapter 5 handles the availability of research data
Chapter 6 is about reproducible research, research code and software
Chapter 7 explains the purpose of replicating studies
Chapter 8 details study preregistration
Chapter 9 offers links to online resources
crumbs: 1  Open Science for Music Research

title: 2  Preface
text:
2.1 Plan and schedule
In music research, particularly for music psychology and computational musicology, we should have a repository of information about Open Science and its all areas (open access publication, open data, open code, registration, and replication). Some of this information has been put together for journal articles (Jensenius, 2021; Moss & Neuwirth, 2021), but having a centralised starting point for this would be helpful for training and awareness.
The repository of information can be best done with collaborative writing and compiling the resources together.

title: 2  Preface
text:
Co-authors contacted and established (November 2025)
Online repository coordinated at GitHub, potentially released at a dedicated domain address (not at https://tuomaseerola.github.io)
Topics divided across co-authors and deadlines agreed (December 2025)
Early drafts ready (March 2026)
Release (May 2026)
Potential for a spin-off article and a hardcopy discussed (May 2026)


2.1.1 Writing

Using markdown text, including markdown references [@reference] linked to references.bib file, and utilising within document links. All implemented via Quarto documents at GitHub to compile site/book as needed.
Tracking the progress and issues via GitHub Issues.
Authorship order to be determined based on contribution and made transparent with Contributor Taxonomy.





Jensenius, A. R. (2021). Best versus good enough practices for open music research. Empirical Musicology Review, 16(1), 5–15.


Moss, F. C., & Neuwirth, M. (2021). FAIR, open, linked: Introducing the special issue on open science in musicology. Empirical Musicology Review, 16(1), 1–4.

title: 3  Background
text:
3.1 Open Science and FAIR data
First, the term Open Science/Open Research[^1]: The former is the global term, used by UNESCO and EU, but humanities scholars might be more persuaded by Open Research.
There is a clear room for improvement in music psychology research in terms of transparency (Eerola, 2024).
